  1. Introduction

    My Programming Languages

    1. C (2014 Freshman, UESTC)
      1st, + manuiplate low level stuff.
    2. C++ (2015 Junior, UMN)
      * very useful but not efficient for programming.
    3. Java (2015 [Winter Break], UMN)
      2nd, + efficiently programming, + large number of libraries, + good for web.
    4. Closure (2015 Junior, UMN)
      + functional programming, - not a common langunage today accroding to my knowledge
    5. Python (2015 Senior, UMN)
      - awkward syntactic sugar
    6. Swift (2016 [Summer Break], UMN)
      + modern, * too many new features to learn
    7. JavaScript (2017 Super Senior, UMN)
      3rd, + Node.js enables the backend, + event-driven programming is a more natural programming paradigm in some cases.
    8. C# (2018 First year master, Georgia Tech)
      First job used C# to develop asp.net apps, Bank API

  2. Developing a program

    Developing a program requires its programming languages, tools (e.g. compiler, package manager), runtime/interpreter and libraries (SDK).

    Comparison

    NameLanguageRuntimeLibraryTools
    C++ programC++machine code on amd64, i386, ARM ...c++ standard librayg++
    Java programJavabytecode code on JVMJava SE/EE/MEjavac, jar, javadoc
    .NET programC#/F#/VBMSIL code on .net runtime.NET Core/.NET Framworkdotnet
    Python2 programPythonpython code on Python Interpreter/JythonPython standard librarypython
    JavaScript programJavaScriptJS code on broswer/node.jsNode.js APInodejs, npm

    Runtimes can be implemented as either hardware, such as amd64 and ARM, or software such as JVM and .net CoreCLR
    Interprets can [only] be implemented as software, such as Python.

    A runtime/interpret defines a standard/specification of how to interpret code, and this standard/specification can have multiple concrete implementations. For example, both Intel and AMD processor implement amd64. Python interpreter has the traditional C version python interpreter and Java version's Jython.

    Library/Standard/Specialization also can have multiple implementations. For example, Java EE specialization has Tomcat and Glassfish.

    The feature that a program can support mutliple languages totally depends on the compilers. For example, .NET compiler can compile C# and F# to MSIL. If Java code can also be compiled into MSIL, then .NET will also support Java.
